Barbara Jordan was a lawyer, educator, and politician who was a leader in the Civil Rights Movement. Barbara Jordan became the first Black person to be elected to the Texas Senate in 1966, and the first woman and first Black person to be elected to Congress from Texas in 1971. She was best known for her powerful opening statement at the House Judiciary Committee hearings during the impeachment process against Richard Nixon, and as the first Black woman to deliver a keynote address at the 1976 Democratic National Convention. Barbara was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by Bill Clinton in 1994 for her work as a political trailblazer. While Barbara never explicitly acknowledged her sexual orientation in public, she was open about her life partner of nearly 30 years, Nancy Earl. It‚Äôs pretty powerful knowing that Barbara was the first Black Queer Woman to break the glass ceiling in many ways throughout her life. #blackhistorymonth #blackhistoryisamericanhistory #pride365

In Jim Crow America, the discriminatory "brown paper bag test" emerged as a metric to exclude people whose skin color was darker than a typical paper bag. But while the test often took place at historically Black universities, nightclubs, and professional networks, this practice actually has its origins in American slavery. In those days, enslaved Black people who were light-skinned ‚Äî and often the descendants of their own enslavers ‚Äî were frequently given better treatment on plantations. This usually meant working inside the house instead of out in the fields, gaining an education, and sometimes even being freed. By contrast, newly arrived enslaved people from Africa typically had darker skin tones and were sent to do the most demanding physical labor. By the time slavery ended and Jim Crow began, many light-skinned descendants of enslaved people had started to form their own clubs based on a presumed shared European ancestry. And tragically, some of these societies chose to shut out darker-skinned Black people by literally using a paper bag to determine whether they were "light" enough to gain entrance. Meanwhile, other institutions used the principle of the test ‚Äî requiring applicants to submit a photo of themselves before they could be allowed inside.
